questions.question: 1. Which of the following oscillations is considered a free oscillation?

explanations.a: Correct. SHM is the natural oscillation without external force or damping.
explanations.b: Not correct. Damped oscillation loses energy over time.
explanations.c: Not correct. Forced oscillation requires external driving force.
explanations.d: Not correct. Critical damping prevents oscillation.

questions.question: 2. In damped oscillations, energy of the system:

explanations.a: Not correct. Energy cannot remain constant due to damping.
explanations.b: Correct. Energy is lost due to friction or resistance.
explanations.c: Not correct. No system can gain energy continuously without external source.
explanations.d: Not correct. Infinite energy is not possible.

questions.question: 3. Which type of damping allows the system to return to equilibrium in the shortest possible time without oscillating?

explanations.a: Not correct. Under damping produces oscillations.
explanations.b: Not correct. Over damping takes longer to reach equilibrium.
explanations.c: Correct. Critical damping achieves fastest return without oscillations.
explanations.d: Not correct. Free oscillation has no damping.

questions.question: 4. In forced oscillation, when the frequency of the driving force matches the natural frequency of the system, the phenomenon is called:

explanations.a: Not correct. Attenuation refers to reduction of amplitude.
explanations.b: Correct. Resonance occurs when driving and natural frequencies match.
explanations.c: Not correct. Critical damping is related to stopping oscillations.
explanations.d: Not correct. Superposition refers to addition of waves.

questions.question: 5. Which graph best represents displacement versus time for a free simple harmonic oscillator?

explanations.a: Not correct. Straight line indicates uniform motion, not oscillation.
explanations.b: Not correct. Exponential decay represents damping.
explanations.c: Correct. SHM is represented by sine or cosine wave.
explanations.d: Not correct. Parabolic is for uniformly accelerated motion.
